I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. Some people may criticise that case of aggression, the harsh and repulsive way of handling women they are presented as parody characters for hate-sex, with one monotonous characterisation in different excuses enough to make us enjoy the story with its found humour.

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The phrases “Mandarin” and “Castles in the Sand” are used frequently throughout. Characters, townsfolk, hate one and love the other one. It is apparent that there is some sort of conspiracy at work but you can’t quite put your finger on what it is.
